creditline: The William Hood Dunwoody Fund, gift of funds from the Paintings Curatorial Council, and the Anne and Hadlai Hull Endowment for Art Acquisition
description: group of figures at water's edge, with one figure wading, holding a long stick into the water; twilight; darker clouds tinged with red high in sky; some white clouds and blue sky in middle of image; belt of trees at right; windmill at left on horizon in distance
marks: Signature and Label at bottom center, in brown: [L. Linnell. f.]
medium: Oil on paper laid on panel
text: Linnell was one of the most successful and influential British landscape painters in the early 1800s. He was among the first artists to regularly paint outdoors along the River Thames in London and in its rustic suburbs, and he captured natural phenomena with sublime intensity. His poetic view of nature resonated throughout the 19th century in the works of his many British and American imitators, particularly the New England circle of Transcendentalists who defined the early American landscape by infusing nature with lyrical spirituality.
title: Evening, Storm Clearing Off
